quiz.title: Chemistry: Unit 1 Quiz 6
quiz.subtitle: 1.6: Measuring Volume: Graduated Cylinders, Beakers, Flasks
quiz.subject: Chemistry

questions.question: What is the curved surface of a liquid in a graduated cylinder called?
questions.explanation: The meniscus is the curve seen at the top of a liquid in response to its container.

questions.question: When measuring the volume of water in a graduated cylinder, where should you take the reading?
options: At the top of the curve.
At the bottom of the meniscus.
In the exact middle of the curve.
It doesn't matter as long as you are consistent.
questions.explanation: To get an accurate reading, you must read the volume at the lowest point of the downward-curving meniscus.

questions.question: To avoid 'parallax error' when reading a measurement, you should:
options: Look at the cylinder from above.
Look at the cylinder from below.
Read the measurement at eye level.
questions.explanation: Parallax error occurs when a measurement is viewed from an angle. Being at eye level ensures accuracy.

questions.question: Which of the following is the standard SI unit for liquid volume in a chemistry lab?
questions.explanation: Milliliters (mL) and Liters (L) are the primary units used for volume in chemical measurements.

questions.question: Why are beakers and Erlenmeyer flasks NOT recommended for precise volume measurements?
options: They have wide openings that allow evaporation.
Their markings are only approximate with high margin of error.
They can only hold hot liquids.
questions.explanation: The markings on beakers and flasks are usually accurate only within 5-10%, whereas graduated cylinders are much more precise.

questions.question: You need to measure exactly 25.0 mL of a solution. Which tool is the best choice?
questions.explanation: A graduated cylinder is specifically designed for accurate volume delivery and measurement.

questions.question: What is the 'displacement method' used to measure?
options: The volume of an irregular solid.
questions.explanation: By dropping a solid into a known volume of liquid, the change in volume represents the volume of the solid.

questions.question: If a graduated cylinder has markings every 1 mL, to what decimal place should you estimate your reading?
questions.explanation: In science, you always record all certain digits plus one estimated digit (one-tenth of the smallest scale division).

questions.question: 1.0 liter is equivalent to how many milliliters?
questions.explanation: The prefix 'milli-' means one-thousandth, so there are 1,000 milliliters in one liter.

questions.question: True or False: When measuring volume, the container should be placed on a flat, level surface.
questions.explanation: Holding the cylinder in your hand can cause it to tilt, leading to an incorrect reading of the meniscus.
